Father and Son Wolman Discuss Environment
A pair of Wolmans in the
Garret Room at the Library
turned the Wednesday Noon
Series into a self-proclaimed Dr.
Jekyll and Mr. Hyde
presentation. The father and son
duo of Abel Wolman, professor
emertius, and M. Gordon
Wolman, Geography, launched
into a lively give-and-take
discussion on the environmental
situation.
Abel Wolman referred to his
son throughout the discussion as
Professor Wolman, receiving

from his son the title of Doctor
Wolman.
Roughly delineated as the
optimistic elder and the
doom-saying son, they provided
the capacity alidience with an
hour of clever dialogue and
question which was enlivened
through-out by the tit-for-tat
exchange between sire and son.
"I guess my optimism is an
eternal one," the senior Wolman
said. He is professor emertits of
Sanitary Engineering, and is
widely respected for his work in

environmental matters. His
work, as he is fond of saying, has
"spanned half a century," and
he looks at questions raised in
the current surge of
environmental interest from
considerable perspective. His son

"Robert Galloway White, the Court finds you

An event. Sometmng that happens.
An act. Something that is caused to
happen. An existential event. Either/or.
Either we act on the faith of our
consciences, or the war will continue to
happen. The artist at once acts and
views the action, and with his creation,
the act transcends itself and affirms its
existential nature, and we are allowed to
Participate. By the grace of the artist,
We are allowed the experience. And we
must beg forgiveness for the lack of our
own acts.

women acted, striking out with
homemade napalm against the absurdity
of events around them, burning paper
that is part of that absurdity, and thus
real, and yet at the same time is an
unreal symbol of the absurdity of
acting. A paradox, a further absurdity
that rises directly from the ashes of war.
In October of 1968, the absurdity
was extended. A trial before a court
that could not find them anything but
guilty for their actions; to do otherwise

would be to allow our peers to become
judges of our morality, a dangerously
intolerable sutuation. Yet to find these
people guilty—to say to the world that
they are to blame—once again absurd,

the black ashes of the war contrasting
with the purity of the act.
Daniel Berrigan is the artist, at once
the participant and the viewer, suffering
the tortures of introspection to give us
with the Trial of the Catonsville Nine, a

creation that presents us with the act
and its personal, legal and moral
dilemmas.

presentation by Center Stage moves the
act of burning 350 1-A draft files out of
the ordinary realm. On this level we see
its rightness; we see that the Catonsville
Nine were certainly Not Guilty. Yet
their trial clearly must end in a guilty
verdict, a fact that the lofty pedestal of
artistic creation allows us to see clearly
and understand, the wider vision we
receive by understanding the essential
innocence of the act brings the myopic
sight of the guilty verdict into focus.

an old theme. Ghandi and Martin
Luther King were there with the Nine,
but there was something more—an
attmipt to bridge the gap between the
spiritual and the physical which Ghandi
and King left to the inevitable forces of
history. This is why the Nine did not
burn one symbolic file, as the Judge
suggested, but burned 350. The act was
Teal. This is why Mary Moylan is still at

large. She really is Not Guilty. This act
was not surrounded by events, but was
reaffirmed by further acts.
Reality
By the act, the Nine took their leap
towards the construction of a new
reality, a reality that recognizes their
innocence. The paradoxical nature of
their Guilt/Not guilt is comforting, for
we are used to such feelings. But the
Nine's attempts at resolving that
paradox are disturbing. Their legal
arguments against the war after the jury
has left are the beginnings of the
foundations for the new reality within
the old; their flight from imprisonment
an affirmation that new reality does
exist on a qhysical plane.
The act was real because it destroyed.
The creation of play is real because it
views the act as real, and begins to
affirm the culture of the new reality,
forming it from the justice of the old. In
performing the act and in making it a
work of art, Daniel Berrigan unites for
us the spiritual, political and cultural
revolutions.

productive ROTC programs in
operation. In the words of Col.
Parmly, "I could care less how
much Uncle Sam has to spend."

schools requiring participation in

As you sit in your prison cell on "Death
Row," for the first time in your life you really
begin to take an honest look at yourself. As you
gaze about you at the rest of the men waiting to
die in the Gas Chamber, it comes over you that
freedom, love, and a sense of belonging have only
been words to you— you have never had them in
reality.
You are still in deep shock. The cold, stern
voice of the black robed Judge echoes harsh and
cruel in your ears; it seems as though it is a
dream, that this can't be true, that you will wake
up and find yourself home with your loved ones.
But his voice is loud and clear, and as long as
there is a breath in your body it will haunt you:
"Robert Galloway White, the Court finds you
guilty of murder in the first degree, and it
sentences you to be taken to the Maryland
Penitentiary, placed in Solitary Confinement on
Death Row, and to die by the administration of
lethal gas, and may God have mercy on your
soul."
As you look at the condemned men around
you, you know for sure that this isn't a dream,
but is reality—that one day, if you lose your
appeal, it will be your turn to walk through that
Green Door where the gas chamber is, and you
wonder how you will accept the fact that you
must die.
Are you ready to take this trip back through
the past with me, and see and understand that
death could only be a sweet relief from the
lonely, cruel, bitter hell called Death Row? How
many times do you kill a man that is awaiting
death? Are you aware of the terrible mental
torture, how often you will wake up screaming
out that you are dead? You die a little each day
you spend there.
It was so quiet I could hear a pin drop when I
was placed in my cell. I looked around me and
saw four men waiting for death just like me, I
had been told that one of them was going to die
that night, in a few hours, and my mind was
thinking, "which one?" There were two white
men, and with myself, three black men with ten
more up-stairs. I gazed around me in a daze; then
I saw the Green Door and knew I was on the
execution floor. A voice called out my name;
they already had the wire from the grapevine
that I would be here. Yet strange as this may
sound, for the first time I felt that all hope was
not gone—the very fact that my name was known
gave me encouragement.
Suddenly I knew that birth is not the true
beginning of life; with all my heart and soul I
knew that here in this Death House was my
beginning. Although I was thirty years old, it wasi

as if I had been asleep for all those years. Neither
God, nor family, nor anyone else had meant
anything to me, for in being born a bastard, and
black, I truly thought and believed that no one
really wanted me or loved me. Therefore, I had
learned to build a wall around myself to hide my
true feelings, and to show everyone that I didn't
need or care for them either; more and more I
had found myself living a lie—a life of crime and
fast women. I was too proud to ask for help, or
even to admit that all I really wished for was to
be wanted for myself and to be loved.
Now it is almost ten O'clock and one of the
cell doors is being opened and there are officers
and chaplains all around; it is time for the
Execution. The prisoner is a black brother and he
comes out of the cell walking tall; he even has a
smile on his lips. Though I don't know him, I
find my heart and even my prayers going out
that he may get a stay of execution. I watch him
go from cell to cell saying goodbye and now he is
at mine. I look into brown eyes that are clearer
than a bright day and see on his face only peace
and a trace of sadness, and his voice is soft as he
tells me to keep my chin up and to fight
hard—and I was without words for the first time
in my life. What could I tell him who was about
to walk his last mile? I could only say that I am
praying that a stay will come. I found myself
weeping because I knew he was sincere, that he
cared about me. Yet he was going to die if the
phone did not ring for a stay of execution. But
the phone did not ring and he walked very slow
and straight through the Green Door and the
door was closed, I heard a motor running and felt
the floor shake and I knew that they were killing
him.
When it was over they must have taken him
out another way, because I never saw him again.
But in my heart and soul, although he was dead,
I knew my thoughts of him would never
die—that I would remember him until I died. I
wonder if I can face death as humbly as he did?
At that moment I knew he was much more of a
man than I.
So for the first time in my life I found I had
no place to hide or to run to...that now was the
time to become a man. I took a long look at
myself and what I saw made me sick with shame.
God, how it hurts to admit you have been a
damn fool!
Was it too- late for me to become a man?
Could I find the strength and understanding to
confess my faults and, even more, to correct
them? Man, it is really tough to admit you have
been cruel, selfish, and wrong in your dealings
with your family and with society. Right then I

learned that although physically one may be
male, unless one has humility, compassion and
understanding, one can never be a man in the
true sense, and I knew that, more than anything
else, I wanted to live and to be a man.
All my life I had run from the truth and
couldn't face my problems, but here in Death
Row my running had to stop; there was no where
to run to now but to death. I began to learn that
love was sacrifice, that one must give if one
wants to receive, and that I had taken all and
given nothing in return. All of my life I had run
from God, wanting no part of him. And now for
the first time in my life I found myself on my
knees. What could I say to God, whom I had
rejected? All I could find to say was, "Help me
and forgive me my wrong," and yet my prayer
was answered.
As the months go slowly by, I realize that I am
not alone, that I can endure more than I
believed, and I learn to live each day with hope.
But I see the terrible heart-breaking suffering of
my mother and my family and it tears me to
pieces to know I am to blame for it. For they
never give up hope and there is love from them
for me that makes me stronger to fight and to
believe that I will not be put to death. I learn to
care and to love my fellow inmates waiting to die
as I am. Again I say that death would be sweet
relief from the stead torture of dying bit by bit
on Death Row. Death Row was truly my
awakening and it was there I was born again to
become a real man.
Much has been said pro and con about capital
punishment, but it is hard for me to understand
how the most powerful country in the world can
still believe in an eye for an eye and a life for a
life. You, society, are admitting defeat in your
structure for only the poor die, black and white,
and yet you say you are just. We can conquer
space and go to the moon and yet we have failed
in controling crime in America and our Death
Houses are filled. Man has come a long way from
the Stone Age and the Jet Age, yet such barbaric
laws as the death penalty are still on the books.
America has the highest crime rate and society
must admit that part of the blame rests upon it
and upon America's out-dated penal system,
which does not place enough emphasis on
rehabilitation. Each criminal is a potential
murderer or rapist if he is not rehabilitated.
Surely in America with all our riches we can do
this. It is not only the criminals that need to be
awakened, but also society.

The trial of the Catonsville Nine
By MICHAEL HILL
An event. Sometmng that happens.
An act. Something that is caused to
happen. An existential event. Either/or.
Either we act on the faith of our
consciences, or the war will continue to
happen. The artist at once acts and
views the action, and with his creation,
the act transcends itself and affirms its
existential nature, and we are allowed to
Participate. By the grace of the artist,
We are allowed the experience. And we
must beg forgiveness for the lack of our
own acts.
In May of 1968, seven men and two
women acted, striking out with
homemade napalm against the absurdity
of events around them, burning paper
that is part of that absurdity, and thus
real, and yet at the same time is an
unreal symbol of the absurdity of
acting. A paradox, a further absurdity
that rises directly from the ashes of war.
In October of 1968, the absurdity
was extended. A trial before a court
that could not find them anything but
guilty for their actions; to do otherwise

would be to allow our peers to become
judges of our morality, a dangerously
intolerable sutuation. Yet to find these
people guilty—to say to the world that
they are to blame—once again absurd,

the black ashes of the war contrasting
with the purity of the act.
Daniel Berrigan is the artist, at once
the participant and the viewer, suffering
the tortures of introspection to give us
with the Trial of the Catonsville Nine, a

creation that presents us with the act
and its personal, legal and moral
dilemmas.
The creation of this work and its
presentation by Center Stage moves the
act of burning 350 1-A draft files out of
the ordinary realm. On this level we see
its rightness; we see that the Catonsville
Nine were certainly Not Guilty. Yet
their trial clearly must end in a guilty
verdict, a fact that the lofty pedestal of
artistic creation allows us to see clearly
and understand, the wider vision we
receive by understanding the essential
innocence of the act brings the myopic
sight of the guilty verdict into focus.
But this is in many ways variations on
an old theme. Ghandi and Martin
Luther King were there with the Nine,
but there was something more—an
attmipt to bridge the gap between the
spiritual and the physical which Ghandi
and King left to the inevitable forces of
history. This is why the Nine did not
burn one symbolic file, as the Judge
suggested, but burned 350. The act was
Teal. This is why Mary Moylan is still at

large. She really is Not Guilty. This act
was not surrounded by events, but was
reaffirmed by further acts.
Reality
By the act, the Nine took their leap
towards the construction of a new
reality, a reality that recognizes their
innocence. The paradoxical nature of
their Guilt/Not guilt is comforting, for
we are used to such feelings. But the
Nine's attempts at resolving that
paradox are disturbing. Their legal
arguments against the war after the jury
has left are the beginnings of the
foundations for the new reality within
the old; their flight from imprisonment
an affirmation that new reality does
exist on a qhysical plane.
The act was real because it destroyed.
The creation of play is real because it
views the act as real, and begins to
affirm the culture of the new reality,
forming it from the justice of the old. In
performing the act and in making it a
work of art, Daniel Berrigan unites for
us the spiritual, political and cultural
revolutions.
